monolithic architecture or micro services well with a monolithic architecture all your processes are
tightly coupled in one application and this is actually how we built things when I joined Amazon I joined as a
software engineer and if you can believe it at the time there were only a couple dozen software engineers at Amazon and
we all worked on one big piece of code that we called obidos and depending upon
how you use two obidos they could do almost anything it ran the retail website it also ran our customer service
centers and it could run our fulfillment centers and one of the things that we learned pretty quickly is that
monolithic software doesn't scale as our software teams grew into the hundreds we
were constantly stepping on each other's toes by breaking the software build or simply struggling to make changes to an
ever-growing codebase what we learned was monolithic software limits
experimentation and it makes it hard to implement new ideas it's also increases
availability problems because a single small problem in your monolithic application can cause impact to lots of
other things it also impacts scaling because with a monolithic application if
you need to scale one part of the application you need to scale the whole application now with a microservices
architecture an application is built as independent components that run each
application process is a separate service and that's where they become so valuable because you can iterate on each
micro service to deliver just the functionality the customers of those services need and at Amazon we
discovered that by factoring our software into small services we could move a lot more quickly something we
were eager to do so we started building services for everything and in a few years we had hundreds of services we had
services for customer information services for personalization information all of these little tiny services
replace the obidos the monolithic software application this was a pretty innovative idea back then but it's even
